page.title: 04THE ATHENAEUM
page.content:
The Athenaeum was constructed in l780 as a coachhouse with a shippen underneath. It belonged to Leasgill House. In l872 it was given to the village as a present to be used as a meeting place. It was called The Athenaeum after the owner's (Mr. Angles) gentlemans' club in Liverpool called The Athenaeum Club and it remained the same until l927 when the stage was moved to the other side of the hall and the library was dismantled to make room for the cloakrooms and a small Kitchen which was built. A new floor was put into the main hall and the entrance was moved to its present position.
In l984 the people of the village began a fund to raise money to renovate and up date the building.
